page.title: Aerospace industry in the United Kingdom

rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you.
rev.diff:
Line 210: Line 210:
===Spaceplanes===
===Spaceplanes===
''Main article: [[Skylon]]''
''Main article: [[Skylon]]''
â
[[File:Skylon climbing.jpg |300px |right |thumb |[[Reaction Engines Skylon]]]]
 
* British company [[Reaction Engines Limited]] is currently developing a [[SSTO]] [[spaceplane]] called [[Skylon]] with funding from the [[ESA]] and private investors.<ref name=sf20110125>{{cite web | url = http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/faq.html| title = Skylon FAQ| author = | date = 2010| work =Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Reaction Engines Limited| accessdate = 25 January 2011}}</ref> The British Government partnered with the [[ESA]] in 2010 to promote [[Skylon]].<ref>[http://www.parabolicarc.com/2010/09/22/uksa-reviews-skylon-sabre/]</ref> This design was pioneered by [[Reaction Engines Limited]],<ref>[http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/faq.html#q6 Reaction Engines Limited FAQ]</ref><ref>[http://www.ukspaceagency.bis.gov.uk/19661.aspx]</ref> a company founded by [[Alan Bond (rocket developer)|Alan Bond]] after [[HOTOL]] was canceled.<ref name="ReactionEngines1">[http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/ Reaction Engines Ltd 2006]</ref> The Skylon spaceplane has been positively received by the British government and the [[British Interplanetary Society]].<ref name=gh220211>{{cite web |url=http://theglobalherald.com/space-the-development-of-single-stage-space-flight/11656/ |title= SSTO spaceplane is coming to Great Britain|author=Robert Parkinson |date= 2-22-11|work=Space:The Development of Single Stage Flight |publisher=The Global Herald |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Pending a successful engine test in June 2011,<ref name=uk20110127>{{cite web |title=Skylon Test Date|publisher=UK Parliament |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmbis/writev/735/73522.htm#Technological Background |author=|date=21 January 2011|accessdate = 2011-01-27}}</ref> the company will begin Phase 3 of development with the first orders expected around 2011-2013.<ref name=uk20110127/>
* British company [[Reaction Engines Limited]] is currently developing a [[SSTO]] [[spaceplane]] called [[Skylon]] with funding from the [[ESA]] and private investors.<ref name=sf20110125>{{cite web | url = http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/faq.html| title = Skylon FAQ| author = | date = 2010| work =Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Reaction Engines Limited| accessdate = 25 January 2011}}</ref> The British Government partnered with the [[ESA]] in 2010 to promote [[Skylon]].<ref>[http://www.parabolicarc.com/2010/09/22/uksa-reviews-skylon-sabre/]</ref> This design was pioneered by [[Reaction Engines Limited]],<ref>[http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/faq.html#q6 Reaction Engines Limited FAQ]</ref><ref>[http://www.ukspaceagency.bis.gov.uk/19661.aspx]</ref> a company founded by [[Alan Bond (rocket developer)|Alan Bond]] after [[HOTOL]] was canceled.<ref name="ReactionEngines1">[http://www.reactionengines.co.uk/ Reaction Engines Ltd 2006]</ref> The Skylon spaceplane has been positively received by the British government and the [[British Interplanetary Society]].<ref name=gh220211>{{cite web |url=http://theglobalherald.com/space-the-development-of-single-stage-space-flight/11656/ |title= SSTO spaceplane is coming to Great Britain|author=Robert Parkinson |date= 2-22-11|work=Space:The Development of Single Stage Flight |publisher=The Global Herald |accessdate=28 February 2011}}</ref> Pending a successful engine test in June 2011,<ref name=uk20110127>{{cite web |title=Skylon Test Date|publisher=UK Parliament |url=http://www.publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201011/cmselect/cmbis/writev/735/73522.htm#Technological Background |author=|date=21 January 2011|accessdate = 2011-01-27}}</ref> the company will begin Phase 3 of development with the first orders expected around 2011-2013.<ref name=uk20110127/>
